Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: The Climatology and Causal Mechanisms of the Early Morning Upward Plasma Drift at Equatorial Latitudes
Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this study is to gain a better understanding of the mechanisms of equatorial electrodynamics in the pre-sunrise ionosphere. Strong upward plasma drifts have been observed by satellites and radars in the early morning hours at equatorial latitudes during the recent solar minimum. The investigators will analyze measurements from the C/NOFS satellite and the Jicamarca radar to infer the morphology (local time, longitudinal, and seasonal variations) of the early morning vertical drift. Comprehensive physical models, the Whole Atmosphere Model (WAM), the Global Ionosphere and Plasmasphere model (GIP) and the Thermosphere-Ionosphere-Mesosphere Electrodynamic General Circulation Model (TIME-GCM) will be used to interpret the observations and to investigate the causal mechanisms of the early morning upward drift. The influence of the early morning upward drift on the thermosphere and ionosphere near dawn and in the daytime will also be estimated. The study combines observations, theory and modeling to achieve a better understanding of the dynamics of the upper atmosphere and the physical processes leading to the early morning upward drifts. The results will help improve the prediction of ionospheric irregularities, which cause GPS scintillation and radio communication outages in the equatorial ionosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focuses on investigating ionospheric electrodynamics at low-latitude region during nighttime and early morning periods. Particularly on how the thermospheric dynamics lead to these unusual upward drift and how these drifts impact the ionosphere morphology. The state-of-the-art coupled model called the whole atmosphere model-global ionosphere plasmasphere model (WAM-GIP) developed at NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center as well as the community Natioal Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Thermosphere-Ionosphere-Electrodynamics General Circulation Model (TIEGCM) were carried out for several simulation studies. Satellite data from the Communications/Navigation Outage Forecasting System (C/NOFS) mission were used for comparisons. Simulation results were also used to support a CubeSat development called INSPIRESat-1 in the University of Colorado Boulder (CU). 

Our study using the TIEGCM has shown that the early morning upward drift is largely related to the F-region dynamo in the nighttime. Simulation from the WAM-GIP also found significant upward drift occurs during post-midnight period that is similar to satellite observation from the C/NOFS mission during solar minimum condition. Our simulation results show good comparison with C/NOFS observation and simulation experiments suggested that the post-midnight upward drift observed by the satellite is closely related to the local wind dynamics associated with the thermospheric midnight temperature maximum (MTM). Results are published in AGU journal JGR Space Physics in 2016. Using the WAM-GIP with realistic solar and geomagnetic drivers, our study also demonstrate that the model is capable of capturing day-to-day variability that were shown in previous studies. Our simulations show that the relative variability is much larger at night than in the daytime, due to much lower background density, and depended strongly on latitude and local time. Additional simulations were also performed to distinguish the contributions to the variability from solar activity, geomagnetic activity, and lower atmospheric perturbations. Results show that globally, geomagnetic activity is the main contributor to the peak ionospheric density variability, followed by lower atmosphere perturbation, and then solar activity. For ionospheric total electron content variability, again, geomagnetic activity is the main contributor, followed by solar activity, and then lower atmosphere perturbation. These results were published in AGU journal JGR Space Physics in 2018. Some of the simulation results were also used to support a student CubeSat mission for satellite orbit simulations and targeted science objectives.

Results from this project have also been presented in several domestic and international conferences in the format of oral and poster presentations. The project has also used to partially support a graduate student in CU Aerospace Department, who helps to carry out C/NOFS satellite data analysis and satellite orbit simulations. A visiting student from Taiwan and a self-funded Postdoc have also participated in this project through carrying out numerical model simulations and contributing codes for post-processing. The project has also greatly supported the PI who was a young female scientist in establishing her career in the CEDAR community.
